channel.title: Citibike on A Hugo website
channel.description: Recent content in Citibike on A Hugo website

item.title: Too hot to cycle?
item.description: Last year I played around a bit with the New York Citibike data, and looked a little bit at the different use patterns among among the sexes, and between subscribers and ad hoc users of the service. Being an Englishman, I was also wondering if there were differences between the patterns of bike usage on different sides of the Atlantic, so I recently got hold of the 20 million odd records of Barclay Bike data from the Transport for London open data portal.

item.title: Do women take the scenic route or do men cycle faster?
item.description: In my previous post I started looking at the NY CitiBike data, and the differences between the way men and women use the service. It’s clear men use the service more, and that women’s journeys are generally longer; however it’s not clear if this is because they simply travel slower, or because they aren’t always taking the most direct route. This is a difficult question to answer. Whilst it is easier to know whether the journey time from A to B is longer for men or women, it is not easy to know if the journey was direct.

item.title: Is CitiBike an old boy's club?
item.description: One of the first things you notice when drilling down into the New York Citibike data, is that there are a lot more male users than female. It’s quite a striking difference between the sexes, and has been picked up in the media. In this post I’m going to look at the way Citibike usage differs across the sexes. There are two types of Citibike users: long-term Subscribers to the service, and short term Customers who might only buy a weekly pass.
